ai-iti91:1.1_0: For this was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.
ai-iti91:2.1_0: “Mendicants, this much fine rice is identical.
ai-iti91:2.2_0: The world curses you: ‘You beggar, walking bowl in hand!’
ai-iti91:2.3_0: This is the reason for speaking these reasons.
ai-iti91:2.4_0: Not because they’ve been forced to by kings or bandits, or because they’re in debt or threatened, or to earn a living.
ai-iti91:2.5_0: Rather, because they think: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
ai-iti91:2.6_0: And I thought, “Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.”
ai-iti91:2.7_0: That’s how a gentleman has gone forth.
ai-iti91:2.8_0: Yet they covet sensual pleasures; they’re infatuated, full of ill will and malicious intent. They are unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying mind and undisciplined faculties.
ai-iti91:2.9_0: Suppose there was a firebrand for lighting a funeral pyre, burning at both ends, and smeared with dung in the middle. It couldn’t be used as timber either in the village or the wilderness.
ai-iti91:2.10_0: I say that person is just like this. They’ve missed out on the pleasures of the lay life, and haven’t fulfilled the goal of the ascetic life.
ai-iti91:3.1_0: “They’ve left behind the pleasures of the lay life,
ai-iti91:3.2_0: and miss out on the goal of the ascetic life.
ai-iti91:3.3_0: Ruining it, they throw it away,
ai-iti91:3.4_0: and perish like a funeral firebrand.
ai-iti91:5.1_0: It’s better to eat an iron ball,
ai-iti91:5.3_0: If an unethical person eats toothbrushes
ai-iti91:5.4_0: than to eat the nation’s alms.”
ai-iti91:6.1_0: That is what the Buddha has heard.
